column5: Nouns belonging to this declension class are generally masculines ending in -? in the nominative singular (bog?, grad?, rod?). The only exception are the nouns in -? that inflect as u-stem masculines.

Sometimes (but not yet obligatorily, in contrast to later Slavic languages), in the accusative singular, the beginnings of a difference between an animate and inanimate subgender can be seen, as the genitive may occasionally be used instead of the accusative for animate objects (raba beside rab?).

Nouns with the suffix -(j)an-in-? (graždanin?) also belong to this declension class in the singular, but in the plural they lose the -in- interfix and conform to the consonantal paradigm (graždane, graždan?, graždanem, graždany, graždane, graždanex?, graždany).
Nouns belonging to this declension class are neuters ending in -o in the nominative singular (selo, l?to, m?sto). The only exception are the few neuters that are inflected as s-stems.
Nouns belonging to this declension class are masculines ending in -? preceded by a palatal in the nominative singular (vra??, kral?, koš?).
This paradigm encompasses nouns such as krai that don't appear to be ending in a palatal, but are in fact underlyingly combinations like kraj? and so undergo this declension (kraj -?, kraj -a).
Nouns ending in agentive suffixes -tel-? and -ar-? also belong to this class (u?itel?, u?itelja, u?itelju..., mytar?, mytarja, mytarju...).
The jo-stem declension class encompasses neuters ending in -e (lože, polje, molen?e).
Nouns belonging to this declension class are feminines ending in -a preceded by a hard, non-palatal consonant (žena).
Also belonging to this paradigm are the rare masculines ending in -a (sluga, vojevoda).
Noun belonging to this declension class are feminines ending in -a preceded by a soft, palatal consonant (straža, svešta, mr?ža).
This paradigm also encompasses feminines ending in -i (rabyni, bogyni), -ica (d?vica) and -?ni- (riz?nica), and also masculines ending in -a preceded by a palatal (junoša).

Nouns belonging to this declension class are masculines ending in -? preceded by a hard, non-palatal consonant (?r?v?, gospod?, p?t?). The only exception are a limited number of such nouns belonging to the n-stem paradigm.
Nouns belonging to the i-stem feminine declension are feminines ending in -? in the nominative singular (r???, nošt?,tvar?).
The only exception is the noun kr?v? which undergoes ?v-stem (?-stem) declension.
Nouns belonging to this declension are a rather small group of masculines: ?in?, dom?, led?, med?, mir?, pol?, san?, syn?, vol?, vr?x?.

Nouns belonging to the ?-stem declension (also known as -?v- declension, or v-stem declension) are: buky, brady, c?ly, cr?ky, hor?gy, loky, ljuby, neplody, pr?ljuby, smoky, svekry, žr?ny, kry (this last form is attested in Psalterium Sinaiticum; older sources list the accusative form kr?v? as a lemma).
Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following masculines: d?n?, jelen?, j???men?, kamy, koren?, plamy, remen?, s?žen?, stepen?.
Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following neuters: br?m?, ?ism?, im?, pism?, plem?, s?m?, sl?m?, t?m?, vr?m?.
Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following neuters: ?udo, divo, dr?vo, kolo, nebo, t?lo, slovoand also uxo and oko which have dual forms like i-stems.
The t-stem (also known as nt-stem) paradigm encompasses neuters denoting a young of an animal or human: otro??, agn?, koz?l?, kljus?, os?l?, ov???, tel?, žr?b? etc.
r-stem feminines are the nouns mati and d?šti.
